body.p:
To His Excellency Thos E. Bramlette
Governor of the Comlth of Ky.

Your petitioner A. B. Miller a citizen of Louisville Ky- would represent on oath that he has for the last three years past been in the union army as a private soldier & that his son Charles Miller has also been in the same army for the same time -- That his son was arrested since his return home on a charge of trying to rob a man -- there was no proof in the case except the man who was a Jew he swor that young Miller was trying to rob him -- young Miller was not able to imploy Counsel & his Father your petitioner became parilized from exposure in the army so as to render it allmost impossible for him to leave his House wherefore his son had no aid in his defence & has been convicted for one year to the penitentiary -- your petitioner is well satisfied that his son is innocent of the charge that his son has been a brave soldier & good boy -- wherefore he most sincerely asks you may parden him -- & by so doing relieve an afflicted Father & aged mother
Subscribed & sworn to by the above named petitioner A. B. Miller before me this 7th day of December 1864.
W. B. Hoke N. P. J. C.

Jefferson Cir Ct
vs
Chas Miller
Pardoned
7th Dec/64
